body: Its name, Brooklyn Republic Vodka, radiates the borough's prickly pride. And though this crystalline new spirit does not begin life in Kings County, it achieves its clean aroma, bright flavor and smooth finish there. It's the work of a troika of resident Brooklyn vodka lovers: Gary Shokin, who came to New York from Lithuania some 30 years ago; his
title: FOOD STUFF; More Eastern Parkway Than Eastern Europe

body: ''Barton, it's me; poke your head out the door,'' Lucille Rhodes said into her cellphone as she strolled down the antiseptic white corridor linking the artists' residences known as Westbeth. Moments later, Barton Lidice Benes peeked out. Wearing boxer shorts and a T-shirt, he waved two strangers inside as if they were old friends. The smile on his
title: THE APPRAISAL; An Enclave of Artists, Reluctant to Leave

body: WHEN real estate was booming, many New Yorkers joined in the rush to turn their houses and apartments into ATMs, withdrawing cash through home-equity loans, or flipping them. Now, with property values under pressure and the rental market on fire, they are trying a new move to pull value out of their homes without selling: they are renting out their
title: Leveraged Moveouts

body: CLINTON HILL LOFT $575,000 BROOKLYN: 689 Myrtle Avenue (Spencer Street), #2G A condo with an open kitchen, a raised sleeping area with two closets, an updated bathroom, and a washer and dryer, in a 45-unit factory converted in 2003, with a glass-enclosed rooftop gym. Edwin Chung, Alan Wieder, Corcoran (718) 490-9308, corcoran.com Open house Sunday,
title: On The Market

body: On Tuesday afternoon, a hundred or so parents of New York City public-school children, most of them mothers from the leafier precincts of Brooklyn, gathered outside the Manhattan office of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo to rally against the potential extinguishing of the so-called millionaires' tax. With $1.4 billion for schools cut from the state budget
title: BIG CITY; As Schools Sacrifice, TV Shows Flourish

body: NEW YORKERS have been fleeing Manhattan in search of more affordable housing for so long that just about every neighborhood in the other boroughs has been anointed the city's next great destination for bargains. Despite this well-worn path off the island, however, finding a place to live in some up-and-coming corner of the city can have its
title: Step Away From the Computer

body: MALKA LUBELSKI marched for economic justice last Sunday dressed as Minnie Mouse. In a pink costume with white polka dots and black mouse ears, she circled Zuccotti Park, the epicenter of the Occupy Wall Street protests, carrying a homemade sign that read, ''From the very young, the very old, we are the 99%.'' It would have been one more bit of
title: For Children's Sake, Taking to the Streets

body: Assemblyman Hakeem Jeffries, calling Congress a ''swamp of dysfunction,'' has begun accepting contributions for a race against a fellow Democrat, Representative Edolphus Towns of Brooklyn. Mr. Jeffries said he had not made a final decision to run against Mr. Towns, but in late September he filed paperwork that would allow him to proceed as a
title: Assemblyman Appears Ready to Join Race for Congress

body: The gray, warehouselike structure that occupies a full block front at 470 Vanderbilt Avenue in Brooklyn is a hulking presence in a neighborhood that is changing through gentrification and about to be transformed by the glossy Atlantic Yards development. Mostly vacant for the better part of a decade, the 650,000-square-foot building has been a tire
title: SQUARE FEET; Unconventional Financing Helps Deal for Brooklyn Space

body: FORT GREENE CO-OP $300,000 BROOKLYN: 205 Clinton Avenue (Willoughby Avenue), #3H A one-bedroom one-bath co-op with a foyer and a dining area in the Clinton Hill Cooperatives, a doorman complex. Matthew Pucker, Prudential Douglas Elliman (917) 981-1107; elliman.com Open house Sunday 12 to 1:30 MAINTENANCE: $717 a month PROS: The apartment has a
title: On The Market

body: The pink slips have gone out, and if no deal is reached by Friday, 716 of New York City's lowest-paid workers -- school aides, parent coordinators and other members of school support staffs -- will lose their jobs, the latest victims of budget cuts to the public schools. Nearly 350 schools will be affected, in a scattered pattern, according to a
title: School Layoffs About to Fall Heaviest On the Poorest and Most Struggling

body: FOR most of his six years in New York, Paul Pinizzotto leased a three-bedroom duplex in a squat, no-frills building in Red Hook, Brooklyn. The rent ended up at $2,250 a month. Over the years, he rented out the extra bedrooms to a series of roommates. The apartment was spacious and sunny, but ''it was a place that I slept in,'' Mr. Pinizzotto said.
title: THE HUNT; Personality for Him; Practicality for Her

body: DURING the real estate boom, it seemed that every day brought news of a new condominium project in New York. Big or small, classic or modern, luxurious or merely comfortable -- there would be something to satisfy both buyers' needs and buyers' wallets. But as the fall season begins, this year's crop of condos is sparse. The new and newly converted
title: New Condos: 'Survivor' Edition

body: DURING the real estate boom, it seemed that every day brought news of a new condominium project in New York. Big or small, classic or modern, luxurious or merely comfortable -- there would be something to satisfy both buyers' needs and buyers' wallets. But as the fall season begins, this year's crop of condos is sparse. The new and newly converted
title: New Condos: 'Survivor' Edition

body: SOME two dozen new condominium developments have just started selling or are scheduled to start sales this fall in New York. Among them are: ONE57 At 157 West 57th Street, this 90-story mixed-use tower, planned as the city's tallest residential structure, will have 135 condo units; one57.com 1 MIMA TOWER On the Far West Side at 460 West 42nd
title: New on the Horizon

body: The woman climbs the stairs in the shabby East Village tenement and enters while Larry Fagin is finishing a call with another poetry student. ''How's Aiden? Is he old enough to go to college yet?'' Mr. Fagin asks the man on the phone, making small talk. He motions for the woman to take a seat at the dining table, where her most recent poem is up on
title: In the East Village, a Poetic Mentor Minces Few Words

body: ALONG with the imported chefs and restaurateurs bringing Danish open-faced sandwiches, avant-garde Korean and Spanish fare, specialties from Beirut and Moscow, and even the flavors of Portland, Ore., to New York, some familiar faces on the local restaurant scene will try something new. A pizza master is opening a diner, and a high-end chef is doing
title: FALL RESTAURANT PREVIEW; Fall's Bounty: Flavors From Home and Abroad

body: While New York City may have dodged a bullet from Tropical Storm Irene, its trees did not. From shade trees on side streets in Elmhurst, Queens, to towering tulip trees in Prospect Park in Brooklyn, many toppled, snapped or splintered. The parks department estimated that 1,200 to 1,500 trees on the city's streets were knocked down, and thousands of
title: In Parks and on City Streets, A Toll of Thousands of Trees

body: Miles has been going to Ace Bar all his life. His face has grayed there. Friends have come and gone. He never paid for a drink, but rarely walked out of the East Village bar with an empty stomach. He may have purged his dinner on the floor a time or two, his fellow bar patrons said, but who among them hadn't done the same? Over the past year,
title: As Bars Shut Doors To Dogs, a Tradition Ends

body: It takes a lot to rattle New York straphangers. They have seen and heard (and smelled) it all. And they mostly ignore it. But on a recent Sunday afternoon a woman stopped abruptly just outside the doors of a downtown train on the N and R line, frozen by the sight of two men rolling wildly along the car's floor, their hands grappling for purchase as
title: Stand Clear of the Screaming Shakespeareans, Please

body: Mark Dunlea and his wife, Judith A. Enck, moved to Brooklyn from upstate New York two years ago. Last March, they breached the blurry Clinton Hill border to buy an apartment in a four-story condominium that had replaced an abandoned warehouse in Bedford-Stuyvesant. The couple say they do not feel like pioneers in the gentrification of
title: A Striking Evolution in Bedford-Stuyvesant as the White Population Soars

body: A classic neighborhood spot in a neighborhood without many, Sud Vino & Cucina has already become the kind of place the locals root for after just four months. In a developing corner of Bedford-Stuyvesant, on Bedford Avenue just south of Lexington, the space hits many familiar notes: a long exposed brick wall functions as a rotating art gallery;
title: AT THE TABLE | SUD VINO & CUCINA; Finding a Place in the Neighborhood

body: Opening BETTO Jason Denton is taking a bite out of Brooklyn with this latest venture featuring bruschette, similar to but softer than his signature crostini, along with small plates for sharing, a few pastas and a frequently changing selections of ''furred, feathered and fish'' from small producers, mainly roasted and served for one or more.
title: Off the Menu

body: In a one-bedroom apartment in Clinton Hill, a vintage welder's mask rests artfully on a bookshelf while a rotary telephone sits on a scruffy stand just so. In NoHo, a cartoon-color painting of a woman licking a man's face -- ''Masked Marty Is Mighty Tasty,'' by Leah Tinari -- screams from a wall. And on 11th Avenue in Midtown, a mix of sleek and
title: THE APPRAISAL; Getting a Lived-In Look That Will Look the Way A Buyer Wants to Live

body: The big voice and dramatic flair that served Wanda Imasuen well as a community organizer are turning out to translate nicely to another stage: musical comedy. Ms. Imasuen plays several roles in an updated revival of the fabled 1937 revue ''Pins and Needles'' that aims to demonstrate that when it comes to the struggles of working people, as she puts
title: Cut, Baste, Stitch, Sing!

body: BACK in 2007, when Jenny Salomon and her longtime boyfriend began house-hunting in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, the two seemed poised on the brink of a golden future together. They had met during their student days at Brown University 15 years earlier. Ms. Salomon was a visual artist who was also deeply involved in the world of nonprofit foundations.
title: HABITATS | CLINTON HILL, BROOKLYN; Adopted By a Brownstone

title: On the Market

body: FOR more than five years, Julie Glickman lived in the ground-floor apartment of a Park Slope brownstone. The owners, family friends, lived upstairs. Ms. Glickman paid just $800 a month, and the rent never rose. The railroad-style apartment was charming, though dark. Ms. Glickman would have been happy staying there indefinitely, or at least ''until
title: THE HUNT; A Place With the Family Seal of Approval

body: Opening AMORINO Here gelato will be scooped to create a flower shape, and the petals can be made of different flavors from a list of more than 20, all in the same cup or cone. It's the signature of the chain, which has stores in 50 locations in Europe, and now New York. Free cones from 4 to 7 p.m. on opening day (Thursday): 60 University Place
title: Off the Menu

body: Hers was the hand of a little girl, smooth and quick, when she first learned to open that little iron gate. That was half a century ago, and while the hand aged -- deeper wrinkles, better nails -- the gate remained constant, its creak sounding the arrival of visitors like a doorbell and as much a part of the home on Vanderbilt Avenue as the
title: CRIME SCENE; Ignoring Homes, Thieves Make Off With Just the Gates Guarding Them

body: Here are descriptions from Eric Demby, the organizer of Smorgasburg, of vendors that will be at this new open-air food court in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Most are new, but some have been at Brooklyn Flea before. Smorgasburg will be open on Saturdays from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m., at 27 North Street, between Kent Avenue and the East River (near East River
title: The Vendors: A List of the Smorgasburg Participants

body: Unlike most New Yorkers, who pull up to the flower stand at a deli in search of something to pump up the swell factor at their Tuesday-night dinner parties, Sarah Ryhanen and Nicolette Owen don't find the choice pathetic or even depressing. And they don't agonize. Of course, it helps that they are wizardly professionals. Both run boutique floral
title: TALK; BUD WISE

body: Greenwich Village, May 1 Seven residences, ranging from a 19th-century townhouse where Emily Post once lived to a 350-square-foot apartment, will be open from 1 to 5:30 p.m. for the 13th annual event to benefit the Greenwich Village Society for Historic Preservation. The tour will also include an Italianate home with an elaborately paneled entrance
title: New York City Home and Garden Tours

body: ONE recent Saturday night, two Brooklyn roommates were driving home when they passed something odd: an unmarked box truck parked on a desolate block in Greenpoint, spewing strobe-lit, milky fog. ''We just saw these people in costumes and there's smoke pouring out of this truck, and Axel said, 'Stop, drive back,' '' recalled Jon Ernsberger, 28, a
title: All the World's a Stage, Even the Back of a Truck

author: Rebecca McMackin lives in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, and is a horticulturalist with New York City and a garden designer for Mantis Plant Works
body: AS the new gardener for the recently renovated Washington Square Park, I never suspected that I would be spending such a large part of my day chasing people with dogs away from plant beds. As a dog owner myself, I find it almost impossible to tell something as cute as a French bulldog puppy what to do. But it is absolutely necessary if we want our
title: COMPLAINT BOX | DOG URINE; Why Pets Shouldn't Water Plants

body: T.J. ENGLISH, who chronicled Irish mobsters in ''The Westies,'' Vietnamese gangs in Chinatown in ''Born to Kill'' and the Mafia's pre-Castro Cuba, returns with a swashbuckling, racially charged nightmare about New York City in the 1960s. This is one nightmare worth reliving because Mr. English so vividly recreates an era when, he writes, ''the city
title: BOOKSHELF; A Nightmarish Time In the City Is Revisited

body: In a bid to cut costs at his star-crossed Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn, the developer Bruce C. Ratner is pursuing plans to erect the world's tallest prefabricated steel structure, a 34-story tower that would fulfill his obligation to start building affordable housing at the site. The prefabricated, or modular, method he would use, which is
title: Atlantic Yards Plans to Build Tallest Prefab

body: Fulton Street in Clinton Hill, a few blocks from the neighborhood's rows of stately brownstones, is undergoing a slow makeover, with markets serving farm-raised meats, French cafes and fresh new faces. Opened in December, Hanson Dry is a midcentury-modern-themed cocktail lounge that caters to the young professionals who now call the neighborhood
title: BOîTE; Hanson Dry: Clinton Hill

body: BY day, Antonio Ramos is a medicinal chemist at the drug maker Sanofi-Aventis in Bridgewater, N.J., where he helps develop molecules for prescription drugs. In the evening, he puts his chemistry skill set to a different use: developing formulas for Brooklyn Soda Works, the artisanal soda company he started last year with his partner, Caroline Mak.
title: BRIGHT IDEAS: SLIPSTREAM; A Chemist, An Artist And a Lot Of Fizz

author: E-mail: citycritic@nytimes.com
body: Steak, lobster, McDonald's: Ask students in New York City's public schools what their cafeterias should be serving, and those are the top three answers. Their parents have a lot of suggestions, too, which are rarely any more realistic. Eric Goldstein, the Department of Education executive who oversees school food, fields those suggestions.
title: CITY CRITIC; Hairnets, Yes; Fried Foods, No

body: Myrtle Avenue, a major east-west route through Brooklyn and parts of Queens, was named for the trees that once dotted those boroughs. But by the 1980s, the section of Myrtle that runs through the Brooklyn neighborhoods of Fort Greene and Clinton Hill had earned the nickname ''Murder Avenue'' for its high crime rate and derelict appearance. For
title: SQUARE FEET; Pratt Institute Takes An Interest in Making A Neighborhood Nicer

body: MANHATTAN Tudor City . . . . . . . . . . . $307,000 320 East 42nd Street r 0 f 1 h 0 o 44 weeks 425-sq.-ft. studio co-op in a prewar building; river view, 24-hr. doormen, concierge, renovated kitchen; maintenance $860, 60% tax deductible; listed at $329,000. Brokers: Tudor Realty Services; City Connections. Lower East Side . . . . . . . $425,000
title: Residential Sales Around the Region

body: For Joe Santos, producing and distributing his own gin was a way to say goodbye to the lock-step march of the corporate world and hello to creativity and originality. He wanted to give the gin a name that communicated that. So he invoked a certain New York City borough, the one currently outpacing the others in self-satisfaction. Brad Estabrooke
title: THE TIPSY DIARIES; Pride of Place In Every Drop

body: EVERY January, the mayor stands at a lectern and delivers the State of the City address, a snapshot of the metropolis from 30,000 feet, with a few local details -- a new fishing pier here, a new middle-income housing development there -- tossed in to help make his case that the government is hard at work to make your life better. That's one
title: The State of the Blocks: Not All Rosy

author: E-mail: nocturnalist@nytimes.com
body: At a screening of a movie about Antarctica in Brooklyn on Wednesday night, guests shivered, pressed close together for warmth and breathed curls of vapor into the frigid air. It was, after all, an outdoor event, and the 50 or so cinephiles watched the film huddled on benches around bonfires in a backyard in Clinton Hill, their feet plunked in
title: NOCTURNALIST; For a Film on Antarctica, The Audience Was Cold

title: RECENTLY REVIEWED

body: FOR eight years, Brendan Mason had a great apartment in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn. His one-bedroom rental was in an owner-occupied brownstone with endless prewar charm. On the stoop one flight down, he would drink coffee, socialize with neighbors, have a smoke. His rent was less than $1,500 a month. His partner, Matthew Reuter, had a less compelling
title: THE HUNT; Room for Men to Work and for Astro to Play

Mostly vacant for the better part of a decade, the 650,000-square-foot building has been a tire
title: SQUARE FEET; Unconventional Financing Helps Deal for Brooklyn Space

body: FORT GREENE CO-OP $300,000 BROOKLYN: 205 Clinton Avenue (Willoughby Avenue), #3H A one-bedroom one-bath co-op with a foyer and a dining area in the Clinton Hill Cooperatives, a doorman complex. Matthew Pucker, Prudential Douglas Elliman (917) 981-1107; elliman.com Open house Sunday 12 to 1:30 MAINTENANCE: $717 a month PROS: The apartment has a
title: On The Market

body: The pink slips have gone out, and if no deal is reached by Friday, 716 of New York City's lowest-paid workers -- school aides, parent coordinators and other members of school support staffs -- will lose their jobs, the latest victims of budget cuts to the public schools. Nearly 350 schools will be affected, in a scattered pattern, according to a
title: School Layoffs About to Fall Heaviest On the Poorest and Most Struggling

body: FOR most of his six years in New York, Paul Pinizzotto leased a three-bedroom duplex in a squat, no-frills building in Red Hook, Brooklyn. The rent ended up at $2,250 a month. Over the years, he rented out the extra bedrooms to a series of roommates. The apartment was spacious and sunny, but ''it was a place that I slept in,'' Mr. Pinizzotto said.
title: THE HUNT; Personality for Him; Practicality for Her

body: DURING the real estate boom, it seemed that every day brought news of a new condominium project in New York. Big or small, classic or modern, luxurious or merely comfortable -- there would be something to satisfy both buyers' needs and buyers' wallets. But as the fall season begins, this year's crop of condos is sparse. The new and newly converted
title: New Condos: 'Survivor' Edition

body: DURING the real estate boom, it seemed that every day brought news of a new condominium project in New York. But as the fall season begins, this year's crop of condos is sparse. The new and newly converted

body: SOME two dozen new condominium developments have just started selling or are scheduled to start sales this fall in New York. Among them are: ONE57 At 157 West 57th Street, this 90-story mixed-use tower, planned as the city's tallest residential structure, will have 135 condo units; one57.com 1 MIMA TOWER On the Far West Side at 460 West 42nd
title: New on the Horizon

body: The woman climbs the stairs in the shabby East Village tenement and enters while Larry Fagin is finishing a call with another poetry student. ''How's Aiden? Is he old enough to go to college yet?'' Mr. Fagin asks the man on the phone, making small talk. He motions for the woman to take a seat at the dining table, where her most recent poem is up on
title: In the East Village, a Poetic Mentor Minces Few Words

body: ALONG with the imported chefs and restaurateurs bringing Danish open-faced sandwiches, avant-garde Korean and Spanish fare, specialties from Beirut and Moscow, and even the flavors of Portland, Ore., to New York, some familiar faces on the local restaurant scene will try something new. A pizza master is opening a diner, and a high-end chef is doing
title: FALL RESTAURANT PREVIEW; Fall's Bounty: Flavors From Home and Abroad

body: While New York City may have dodged a bullet from Tropical Storm Irene, its trees did not. From shade trees on side streets in Elmhurst, Queens, to towering tulip trees in Prospect Park in Brooklyn, many toppled, snapped or splintered. The parks department estimated that 1,200 to 1,500 trees on the city's streets were knocked down, and thousands of
title: In Parks and on City Streets, A Toll of Thousands of Trees

body: Miles has been going to Ace Bar all his life. His face has grayed there. Friends have come and gone. He never paid for a drink, but rarely walked out of the East Village bar with an empty stomach. He may have purged his dinner on the floor a time or two, his fellow bar patrons said, but who among them hadn't done the same? Over the past year,
title: As Bars Shut Doors To Dogs, a Tradition Ends

body: It takes a lot to rattle New York straphangers. They have seen and heard (and smelled) it all. And they mostly ignore it. But on a recent Sunday afternoon a woman stopped abruptly just outside the doors of a downtown train on the N and R line, frozen by the sight of two men rolling wildly along the car's floor, their hands grappling for purchase as
title: Stand Clear of the Screaming Shakespeareans, Please

body: Mark Dunlea and his wife, Judith A. Enck, moved to Brooklyn from upstate New York two years ago. Last March, they breached the blurry Clinton Hill border to buy an apartment in a four-story condominium that had replaced an abandoned warehouse in Bedford-Stuyvesant. The couple say they do not feel like pioneers in the gentrification of
title: A Striking Evolution in Bedford-Stuyvesant as the White Population Soars

body: A classic neighborhood spot in a neighborhood without many, Sud Vino & Cucina has already become the kind of place the locals root for after just four months. In a developing corner of Bedford-Stuyvesant, on Bedford Avenue just south of Lexington, the space hits many familiar notes: a long exposed brick wall functions as a rotating art gallery;
title: AT THE TABLE | SUD VINO & CUCINA; Finding a Place in the Neighborhood

body: Opening BETTO Jason Denton is taking a bite out of Brooklyn with this latest venture featuring bruschette, similar to but softer than his signature crostini, along with small plates for sharing, a few pastas and a frequently changing selections of ''furred, feathered and fish'' from small producers, mainly roasted and served for one or more.
title: Off the Menu

body: In a one-bedroom apartment in Clinton Hill, a vintage welder's mask rests artfully on a bookshelf while a rotary telephone sits on a scruffy stand just so. In NoHo, a cartoon-color painting of a woman licking a man's face -- ''Masked Marty Is Mighty Tasty,'' by Leah Tinari -- screams from a wall. And on 11th Avenue in Midtown, a mix of sleek and
title: THE APPRAISAL; Getting a Lived-In Look That Will Look the Way A Buyer Wants to Live

body: The big voice and dramatic flair that served Wanda Imasuen well as a community organizer are turning out to translate nicely to another stage: musical comedy. Ms. Imasuen plays several roles in an updated revival of the fabled 1937 revue ''Pins and Needles'' that aims to demonstrate that when it comes to the struggles of working people, as she puts
title: Cut, Baste, Stitch, Sing!

body: BACK in 2007, when Jenny Salomon and her longtime boyfriend began house-hunting in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, the two seemed poised on the brink of a golden future together. They had met during their student days at Brown University 15 years earlier. Ms. Salomon was a visual artist who was also deeply involved in the world of nonprofit foundations.
title: HABITATS | CLINTON HILL, BROOKLYN; Adopted By a Brownstone

body: FOR more than five years, Julie Glickman lived in the ground-floor apartment of a Park Slope brownstone. The owners, family friends, lived upstairs. Ms. Glickman paid just $800 a month, and the rent never rose. The railroad-style apartment was charming, though dark. Ms. Glickman would have been happy staying there indefinitely, or at least ''until
title: THE HUNT; A Place With the Family Seal of Approval

body: Opening AMORINO Here gelato will be scooped to create a flower shape, and the petals can be made of different flavors from a list of more than 20, all in the same cup or cone. It's the signature of the chain, which has stores in 50 locations in Europe, and now New York. Free cones from 4 to 7 p.m. on opening day (Thursday): 60 University Place
title: Off the Menu

body: Hers was the hand of a little girl, smooth and quick, when she first learned to open that little iron gate. That was half a century ago, and while the hand aged -- deeper wrinkles, better nails -- the gate remained constant, its creak sounding the arrival of visitors like a doorbell and as much a part of the home on Vanderbilt Avenue as the
title: CRIME SCENE; Ignoring Homes, Thieves Make Off With Just the Gates Guarding Them

body: Here are descriptions from Eric Demby, the organizer of Smorgasburg, of vendors that will be at this new open-air food court in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Most are new, but some have been at Brooklyn Flea before. Smorgasburg will be open on Saturdays from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m., at 27 North Street, between Kent Avenue and the East River (near East River
title: The Vendors: A List of the Smorgasburg Participants

body: Unlike most New Yorkers, who pull up to the flower stand at a deli in search of something to pump up the swell factor at their Tuesday-night dinner parties, Sarah Ryhanen and Nicolette Owen don't find the choice pathetic or even depressing. And they don't agonize. Of course, it helps that they are wizardly professionals. Both run boutique floral
title: TALK; BUD WISE

body: Greenwich Village, May 1 Seven residences, ranging from a 19th-century townhouse where Emily Post once lived to a 350-square-foot apartment, will be open from 1 to 5:30 p.m. for the 13th annual event to benefit the Greenwich Village Society for Historic Preservation. The tour will also include an Italianate home with an elaborately paneled entrance
title: New York City Home and Garden Tours

body: ONE recent Saturday night, two Brooklyn roommates were driving home when they passed something odd: an unmarked box truck parked on a desolate block in Greenpoint, spewing strobe-lit, milky fog. ''We just saw these people in costumes and there's smoke pouring out of this truck, and Axel said, 'Stop, drive back,' '' recalled Jon Ernsberger, 28, a
title: All the World's a Stage, Even the Back of a Truck

author: Rebecca McMackin lives in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, and is a horticulturalist with New York City and a garden designer for Mantis Plant Works
body: AS the new gardener for the recently renovated Washington Square Park, I never suspected that I would be spending such a large part of my day chasing people with dogs away from plant beds. As a dog owner myself, I find it almost impossible to tell something as cute as a French bulldog puppy what to do. But it is absolutely necessary if we want our
title: COMPLAINT BOX | DOG URINE; Why Pets Shouldn't Water Plants

body: T.J. ENGLISH, who chronicled Irish mobsters in ''The Westies,'' Vietnamese gangs in Chinatown in ''Born to Kill'' and the Mafia's pre-Castro Cuba, returns with a swashbuckling, racially charged nightmare about New York City in the 1960s. This is one nightmare worth reliving because Mr. English so vividly recreates an era when, he writes, ''the city
title: BOOKSHELF; A Nightmarish Time In the City Is Revisited

body: In a bid to cut costs at his star-crossed Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn, the developer Bruce C. Ratner is pursuing plans to erect the world's tallest prefabricated steel structure, a 34-story tower that would fulfill his obligation to start building affordable housing at the site. The prefabricated, or modular, method he would use, which is
title: Atlantic Yards Plans to Build Tallest Prefab

body: Fulton Street in Clinton Hill, a few blocks from the neighborhood's rows of stately brownstones, is undergoing a slow makeover, with markets serving farm-raised meats, French cafes and fresh new faces. Opened in December, Hanson Dry is a midcentury-modern-themed cocktail lounge that caters to the young professionals who now call the neighborhood
title: BOîTE; Hanson Dry: Clinton Hill

body: BY day, Antonio Ramos is a medicinal chemist at the drug maker Sanofi-Aventis in Bridgewater, N.J., where he helps develop molecules for prescription drugs. In the evening, he puts his chemistry skill set to a different use: developing formulas for Brooklyn Soda Works, the artisanal soda company he started last year with his partner, Caroline Mak.
title: BRIGHT IDEAS: SLIPSTREAM; A Chemist, An Artist And a Lot Of Fizz

author: E-mail: citycritic@nytimes.com
body: Steak, lobster, McDonald's: Ask students in New York City's public schools what their cafeterias should be serving, and those are the top three answers. Their parents have a lot of suggestions, too, which are rarely any more realistic. Eric Goldstein, the Department of Education executive who oversees school food, fields those suggestions.
title: CITY CRITIC; Hairnets, Yes; Fried Foods, No

body: Myrtle Avenue, a major east-west route through Brooklyn and parts of Queens, was named for the trees that once dotted those boroughs. But by the 1980s, the section of Myrtle that runs through the Brooklyn neighborhoods of Fort Greene and Clinton Hill had earned the nickname ''Murder Avenue'' for its high crime rate and derelict appearance. For
title: SQUARE FEET; Pratt Institute Takes An Interest in Making A Neighborhood Nicer

body: For Joe Santos, producing and distributing his own gin was a way to say goodbye to the lock-step march of the corporate world and hello to creativity and originality. He wanted to give the gin a name that communicated that. So he invoked a certain New York City borough, the one currently outpacing the others in self-satisfaction. Brad Estabrooke
title: THE TIPSY DIARIES; Pride of Place In Every Drop

body: EVERY January, the mayor stands at a lectern and delivers the State of the City address, a snapshot of the metropolis from 30,000 feet, with a few local details -- a new fishing pier here, a new middle-income housing development there -- tossed in to help make his case that the government is hard at work to make your life better. That's one
title: The State of the Blocks: Not All Rosy

author: E-mail: nocturnalist@nytimes.com
body: At a screening of a movie about Antarctica in Brooklyn on Wednesday night, guests shivered, pressed close together for warmth and breathed curls of vapor into the frigid air. It was, after all, an outdoor event, and the 50 or so cinephiles watched the film huddled on benches around bonfires in a backyard in Clinton Hill, their feet plunked in
title: NOCTURNALIST; For a Film on Antarctica, The Audience Was Cold

body: FOR eight years, Brendan Mason had a great apartment in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn. His one-bedroom rental was in an owner-occupied brownstone with endless prewar charm. On the stoop one flight down, he would drink coffee, socialize with neighbors, have a smoke. His rent was less than $1,500 a month. His partner, Matthew Reuter, had a less compelling
title: THE HUNT; Room for Men to Work and for Astro to Play
